conclusion: All perceptions of the mind are either impressions or ideas
Ideas are faint copies of impressions
Complex ideas are composed of simple ideas derived from simple impressions
The missing shade of blue counterexample shows a possible exception to the copy principle
Causation is not a real necessary connection but a constant conjunction discovered by experience
Belief is a lively, vivid conception produced by custom or habit
Reason alone cannot motivate action; passions do
Moral distinctions are derived from sentiment, not reason
Virtue is whatever produces pleasure or approbation in a disinterested spectator
Justice is an artificial virtue arising from conventions
Promises are binding because of human convention, not natural obligation
The self is a bundle or collection of perceptions, not a single substance
Personal identity is a fiction created by the imagination
Liberty and necessity are compatible (compatibilism)
The principle of association of ideas operates via resemblance, contiguity, and causation
Sympathy is the mechanism by which we feel the passions of others
Pride and humility are indirect passions requiring a double relation of ideas and impressions
There is no rational justification for induction (the problem of induction)
External objects are not directly perceived; we perceive only impressions
Space and time are composed of indivisible points or minima
All probable reasoning depends on the uniformity of nature assumption
Animals reason in a manner similar to humans via custom and habit
Greatness of mind (magnanimity) is a natural virtue
Benevolence is a natural motive independent of self-interest
Reason is and ought only to be the slave of the passions
All objects of human reason are relations of ideas or matters of fact
Matters of fact are known only through cause and effect
Knowledge of causation comes from experience, not a priori reasoning
The idea of necessary connection arises from custom, not from insight into objects
No amount of finite observation can justify universal causal claims (problem of induction)
Belief is a sentiment or feeling, not a cognitive act
Miracles are violations of laws of nature and thus highly improbable
No testimony is sufficient to establish a miracle unless its falsehood would be more miraculous
There is no demonstrative proof of an external world; we rely on instinct
Liberty is the ability to act according to one's will (compatibilist definition)
Necessity is regularity in nature and in human motives
Reason alone cannot produce action; it must be aided by passion
Skepticism about causation leads to a mitigated or academic skepticism
All probable reasoning presupposes the uniformity of nature
"Ought" cannot be derived from "is" (early statement of the is-ought gap)
Animals learn from experience in the same way humans do
The association of ideas governs thought via resemblance, contiguity, and causation
Superstition and false philosophy arise from unchecked imagination
Excessive skepticism is impracticable and self-refuting
Custom is the great guide of human life
All inferences from experience are effects of habit, not reasoning
There is no rational basis for preferring one uniform experience over another
Free will and moral responsibility are compatible with determinism
Philosophical decisions should be based on experience and observation
A wise man proportions belief to evidence
The moral sentiment is a feeling of approbation or disapprobation
Utility is the primary source of moral approbation
Qualities useful or agreeable to oneself or others are virtuous
Justice is primarily valued for its social utility
Justice is an artificial virtue based on convention and education
Benevolence and humanity are natural virtues
Personal merit consists in qualities useful or agreeable
Self-interest alone cannot account for extensive benevolence
Sympathy enables us to approve of qualities beneficial to society
The monkish virtues (celibacy, fasting, penance) are actually vices
Greatness of mind and dignity are highly esteemed virtues
Moral judgments are universal among mankind when corrected by reflection
Reason discovers the facts of utility, but sentiment approves them
The general good of society is the ultimate standard of morals
Promises create obligation through social artifice
Allegiance to government rests on utility and consent
Chastity and modesty are artificial virtues shaped by society
Good manners and politeness have moral value because they are agreeable
Moral beauty resembles aesthetic beauty in producing pleasure
The distinction between natural and artificial virtues is fundamental
All virtues ultimately reduce to what is useful or agreeable
Humanity is the chief virtue and source of moral praise
Moral philosophy should be practical and improve character
The sentiment of humanity is calm and universal, unlike violent passions
The argument from design resembles an inference to the best explanation
The universe shows marks of intelligent design similar to human artifacts
We cannot infer infinite or perfect attributes from finite effects
The cause of the universe need only be proportioned to its effect
Analogy between the world and a machine is weak and limited
The universe may resemble a vegetable or animal more than a machine
Order could arise from a finite, imperfect, or multiple causes
The existence of evil undermines the inference to a perfectly good designer
A perfectly good and omnipotent deity is incompatible with the amount of evil
Matter may possess an inherent principle of order
The cosmological argument fails to prove an infinite or necessary being
Infinite regress of causes is conceivable
We have no experience of world-creation, so speculation is unwarranted
Theological hypotheses exceed the bounds of human understanding
Mystical and anthropomorphic conceptions of deity are equally unfounded
Skeptical suspension of judgment is the most reasonable attitude
The dispute between theism and atheism may be merely verbal
Genuine theism leads to sincere piety rather than superstition
Religious hypotheses should be judged by ordinary standards of evidence
Apparent design does not prove a single designer
The universe's cause may be indifferent to good and evil
The Epicurean hypothesis holds that particles in random motion eventually produce order
We cannot legitimately attribute moral attributes to the first cause
Excessive skepticism in religion is dangerous to society
True religion consists in moderation and philosophical humility rather than dogma
Ideas differ from impressions only in degree of force and vivacity
Every simple idea has a corresponding simple impression from which it is copied
Memory ideas retain more of the original order and form than ideas of the imagination
The imagination is free to transpose and rearrange ideas but not to create genuinely new simple ideas
The principle of association by resemblance, contiguity, and cause-and-effect governs the train of thought
Causation is the only relation that allows us to go beyond what is immediately present to the senses
The idea of power or necessary connection has no impression-source in external objects
The feeling of necessary connection arises from the mind's customary transition after repeated conjunctions
All probable inferences depend on the relation of cause and effect
The uniformity of nature is an assumption without rational justification
Induction rests entirely on custom and habit, not on reason
There is no demonstrative argument for the existence of body (external objects)
Continued and distinct existence of objects is a fiction of the imagination
The imagination supplies constancy and coherence to interrupted perceptions
The philosophical system of double existence (representations vs. objects) is incoherent
Belief consists in nothing but the vivacity transferred from an impression to a related idea
No belief is ever produced by reason alone
The understanding, when acting alone, wholly subverts itself in matters of probability
Probability of chances arises from the mixture of causes and imperfect habits
Unphilosophical probability arises from general rules that are contrary to specific evidence
The liberty of indifference is incompatible with causation and therefore impossible
Necessity (determinism) is essential to moral responsibility
The influencing motives of the will are always accompanied by felt determination
Reason discovers truth and falsehood but cannot produce volition
Passions are original existences not representative of anything else
Calm passions often determine the will more steadily than violent ones
Direct passions (desire, aversion, joy, grief, hope, fear) arise immediately from good or evil
Indirect passions (pride, humility, love, hatred) require the double relation of ideas and impressions
Pride always has the self as its object
The causes of pride and humility must be agreeable or disagreeable and related to the self
Sympathy is the conversion of another's idea into an impression by the relation to that person
Sympathy is the chief source of moral approbation and disapprobation
Love and hatred are always directed toward other persons, never the self
Esteem and contempt are calmer forms of love and hatred
The passions of love and hatred produce benevolence and anger as secondary effects
Respect and contempt combine love/hatred with humility/pride
Pity is a concern for another's misery produced by sympathy
Malice is pleasure in another's misery without personal injury
The desire of punishment for vice and reward for virtue arises from general rules and sympathy
Strength of mind is the ability to govern violent passions by calmer ones
Will is not a separate faculty but the internal impression accompanying action
Voluntary actions are those preceded by a desire or aversion
Animals possess reason and understanding analogous to humans via custom
Moral distinctions are not derived from reason but from a moral sense or sentiment
Reason can never oppose or produce a passion by showing something false
Virtue is distinguished by the pleasure it excites in a disinterested spectator
Natural abilities (wit, genius) are virtues in the same sense as moral qualities
Justice is an artificial virtue, not natural
The sense of justice arises from reflection on the utility of conventions
Property originates in conventions gradually established for social stability
The rules of justice (stability of possession, transference by consent, performance of promises) are artificial
Promises oblige only because of the convention that language creates expectation
Allegiance to government rests on the utility of authority and the obligation of promises
Chastity and modesty are artificial virtues designed to protect paternity and encourage fidelity
Good manners and politeness are agreeable qualities that receive moral approbation
Natural virtues (benevolence, meekness, charity) please immediately without artifice
The artificiality of justice does not diminish its moral value
Self-interest is not the sole motive of just actions; sympathy and moral sentiment also operate
The obligation to justice is stronger than to other artificial virtues because of greater social necessity
Celibacy, fasting, penance, and mortification are monkish virtues that deserve no approbation
Greatness of mind or magnanimity is a natural social virtue highly esteemed
The general point of view corrects partial sympathy in moral judgments
Moral language (virtue/vice) presupposes a common sentiment among mankind
All human actions admit of some degree of virtue or vice
External actions have no intrinsic moral quality independent of motive
Motive alone determines the morality of an action
Some motives (benevolence, justice) are naturally virtuous even when ineffectual
The ultimate ends of action are never reasonable or unreasonable
Moral approbation is a particular kind of pleasure, distinct from aesthetic or sensory pleasure
Sympathy with the happiness of mankind is the source of our approval of extensive benevolence
Qualities useful to others (justice, fidelity) receive approbation via sympathy
Qualities agreeable to others (politeness, wit) also receive moral praise
Qualities useful or agreeable to the possessor (industry, prudence) are likewise virtuous
The distinction between virtue and talent is merely verbal and conventional
The catalogue of virtues varies across societies but utility remains the core criterion
The sentiment of approbation is calm and general, not violent
Moral beauty is analogous to physical beauty in producing pleasure by conformation
The moral sense is universal when corrected for differences in education and situation
Children and animals exhibit rudimentary moral sentiments via sympathy
The origin of government lies in the need to enforce the rules of justice
The moral obligation to obedience is grounded in long-term interest
Conquest and succession provide only weak titles to authority
The principles of association explain the ease of transitions in thought
Space and time are not infinitely divisible; they consist of minima
Geometrical demonstrations fail when applied beyond certain degrees of minuteness
Fictions of perfect equality and infinite divisibility arise from the imagination's habits
The idea of a vacuum is impossible because it would require perception without impression
The self is nothing but a bundle or system of different perceptions
Personal identity over time is a fiction produced by the smooth transition of resembling perceptions
The ancient philosophy of substance and accident is unintelligible
The modern philosophy of primary and secondary qualities collapses into skepticism
All objects of the understanding are either relations of ideas or matters of fact
Demonstrative reasoning concerns only relations of ideas
Probability concerns matters of fact and real existence
Education forms habits that mimic natural reasoning
Prejudice and authority often override experience and custom
The imagination naturally sides with the rich and powerful in sympathy
Limited generosity is natural; extensive benevolence requires reflection
The party of humankind vs. narrower factions arises from more general sympathy
Philosophy should be modest, acknowledging the narrow limits of human understanding
Impressions of sensation arise from unknown causes, while impressions of reflection arise from preceding ideas
The distinction between impressions and ideas is more properly felt than explained
Some ideas (e.g., of God) are formed by enlarging or compounding ideas derived from experience
The imagination can separate and recombine any ideas that are distinguishable
Distinguishability implies separability in the imagination
Relations of ideas can yield certainty, but matters of fact never can
The contrary of any matter of fact is always conceivable without contradiction
All effects have causes, but we discover causes only through experience
Two objects are causally related only if they are contiguous in time and space and prior effect resembles prior cause
Priority of cause over effect is required for causation
The idea of causation includes three components: contiguity, succession, and necessary connection
We never observe necessity in objects; it is projected from the mind's determination
After repeated conjunctions, the mind is carried by habit from cause to effect
The inference from cause to effect is not determined by reason but by custom
No demonstrative reasoning can prove that unobserved instances will resemble observed ones
The supposition that the future will resemble the past is itself unjustifiable by reason
Belief in causation is non-rational but indispensable for life
The vulgar belief in continued existence arises from the constancy of interrupted perceptions
The philosophical belief in continued existence arises from coherence of interrupted perceptions
The fiction of continued existence smooths over interruptions in perception
Identity is ascribed to objects that undergo gradual change while retaining resemblance
The idea of identity arises from a smooth, uninterrupted survey of related perceptions
The soul or self cannot be a simple impression, for no such constant impression exists
The principle of individuation is neither simplicity nor identity but relation
Modes and substances are fictions created by the imagination's associating tendencies
Abstract ideas are particular ideas annexed to general terms via custom
General terms acquire meaning through the revival of resembling particular ideas
The distinction between particular and general ideas is grounded in custom, not reason
Probability of causes arises when past experience is imperfectly uniform
When causes are opposed, belief is divided proportionally to past frequency
The duration of an object's existence influences probability judgments
Longer existence without change increases the probability of its continuation
Causation, when extended over time, produces a stronger habitual transition
Reason can correct unphilosophical probability by applying general rules
The will is the internal impression we feel when we knowingly give rise to action
Liberty of spontaneity (acting without external constraint) is compatible with necessity
Liberty of indifference (uncaused choice) destroys moral responsibility
Actions are blameworthy only when they proceed from durable qualities of character
Violent passions may excuse actions because they are less durable
Direct passions arise directly from prospects of pain or pleasure
Indirect passions always involve a relation to self or another person
The object of pride is always the self; the object of love is always another
Causes of pride must be peculiar to the self and produce independent pleasure
Custom and repetition strengthen the association in indirect passions
Comparison with others can reverse passions (e.g., envy turns superiority into humility)
Compassion is an uneasy sympathy with another's misery
Envy and malice arise from comparison rather than simple sympathy
The principle of sympathy operates more strongly with those resembling or related to us
Distance in time or space weakens sympathy
General rules correct the partiality of immediate sympathy in moral judgments
Virtue in rags still excites approbation when viewed from the general perspective
Moral sentiment is distinct from self-interest yet often coincides with it
Natural motives (benevolence, resentment) produce virtuous actions without artifice
The three fundamental laws of nature are stability of possession, transference by consent, and promise performance
Property is not a natural relation but a conventional one
The origin of property lies in gradual conventions that arise without explicit agreement
Interest is the first obligation to justice, but sentiment reinforces it
The obligation of promises is entirely artificial and depends on the social practice of language
Interest, though primary, is insufficient alone to motivate justice in large societies
Education and politics reinforce the natural sense of justice
Government arises from the need to compel obedience to the rules of justice
The duty of allegiance is founded on the utility of government and the obligation of promises
Consent of the governed is often fictitious; long possession and present possession provide stronger titles
Moral approbation extends to natural abilities because they are useful or agreeable
The distinction between moral virtues and natural abilities is artificial
Qualities immediately agreeable to the possessor (cheerfulness, wit) are virtuous
Qualities immediately agreeable to others (politeness, modesty) also receive moral praise
The monkish virtues produce misery and deserve no esteem
Heroic virtue (courage, ambition) is admired for its greatness of mind
The sentiment of morals arises from humanity and sympathy with affected parties
Moral judgments presuppose a common point of view independent of our private interest
The correction of sympathy by general rules produces impartial moral verdicts
Vice and virtue are as real as beauty and deformity in producing distinctive feelings
Moral distinctions are universal among humans when differences in situation are removed
Some virtues (generosity, clemency) please immediately; others (justice, fidelity) please by their tendency
The utility of justice is remote, so sympathy with public interest is required for approbation
The circle objection (justice approved for utility, utility approved by moral sentiment) is harmless
Moral sentiment is prior to considerations of utility in the order of explanation
The idea of time arises from the succession of changeable perceptions
Time cannot be perceived without a successive perception
The idea of space arises from the disposition of colored or tangible points
Infinite divisibility leads to contradictions; extension must consist of indivisible minima
Mathematical points are not colored or tangible and thus yield no idea of extension
The fiction of infinite divisibility arises from the imagination's inability to stop
Vacuum is inconceivable because it would require extension without perceptible qualities
The modern distinction between primary and secondary qualities leads to skepticism
Secondary qualities exist only in the mind, yet we project them onto objects
The idea of power is transferred from the mind's felt determination to external objects
Animals form inferences analogous to human causal reasoning through habit
Animal behavior demonstrates the same principles of association and custom
Education implants principles by repetition, mimicking natural habit
Prejudice arises when general rules are misapplied to particular cases
The imagination prefers easy transitions, leading to bias toward the vivid and present
Contiguity and resemblance strengthen belief more than causation alone
Poetry excites belief more easily than history because it operates on the imagination without checks
Eloquence moves us by presenting ideas with vivacity borrowed from passion
Taste in morals and aesthetics follows similar principles of sentiment
Philosophical probability is corrected by general rules derived from experience
Excessive refinement in philosophy leads to skepticism, but moderate skepticism is salutary
Human understanding has narrow limits; philosophy should acknowledge its dependence on instinct and sentiment
Moral approbation is a feeling or sentiment, not a judgment of reason
Reason alone can never produce moral approval or disapproval
The ultimate foundation of morals is a principle of humanity or fellow-feeling
Utility pleases because it tends to promote the happiness of mankind
The agreeable sensation produced by utility is the true source of our approval of virtuous qualities
Qualities useful to others are approved via sympathy with those who benefit
Qualities useful to the possessor (discretion, industry, frugality) also receive moral approbation
Qualities immediately agreeable to the possessor (cheerfulness, greatness of mind) are virtuous
Qualities immediately agreeable to others (politeness, wit, modesty) excite moral praise
All virtuous qualities ultimately reduce to what is useful or agreeable to self or others
Justice derives its moral value chiefly from its artificial character and social utility
Benevolence and humanity are natural virtues that please immediately
The distinction between natural and artificial virtues does not lessen the merit of the latter
Public utility is the sole origin of justice
Private benevolence alone cannot secure large societies; justice is required
Property arises from the social convention of stabilising possession
The rules determining property are framed for the peace and security of society
Transfer by consent and the performance of promises are essential parts of justice
The obligation of promises is artificial and depends on the usefulness of the convention
Fidelity to promises is approved because breach would destroy trust and society
Allegiance to government rests on the general interest and utility of political authority
The original obligation to obedience is founded on the necessity of government for justice
Consent of the governed is often imaginary; utility remains the real foundation
Chastity, modesty, and female fidelity are artificial virtues shaped by social interest
The double standard of sexual morality arises from long-term utility for child-rearing
Good manners, decency, and politeness receive moral approbation as agreeable qualities
The monkish virtues (celibacy, fasting, penance, humility, solitude) are really vices
Monkish virtues produce misery and diminish the capacity for useful action
True virtue consists in qualities that promote active social good
Greatness of mind, dignity, and courage are highly esteemed social virtues
Humanity is the softest and most engaging virtue
Moral sentiment is calm, uniform, and universal when properly corrected
Reason discovers the factual tendency of qualities to promote happiness
Sentiment alone approves those tendencies as virtuous
The is-ought distinction: no "ought" can be derived from "is" without sentiment
Moral distinctions are real and not merely verbal disputes
Moral language presupposes a shared human sentiment
Disagreements in morals usually arise from differing perspectives or narrow sympathy
A properly corrected sympathy adopts a steady and general point of view
From the general point of view, the happiness of strangers affects us via sympathy
Self-interest is a powerful motive but insufficient to explain extensive moral approval
Extensive benevolence requires the aid of reflection and corrected sympathy
The moral sense is the same in all humans when differences of situation are removed
Children, animals, and even savages exhibit rudimentary moral sentiments
Moral beauty is analogous to natural and aesthetic beauty in producing pleasure
The pleasure of moral approbation resembles the secondary pleasure of aesthetic judgment
Virtue in rags excites the same approbation as virtue in prosperity when properly viewed
The utility of justice is remote, so sympathy with public interest sustains its approval
The circle (justice approved for utility, utility approved by sentiment) is virtuous, not vicious
Sentiment is psychologically prior, though reason informs us of useful tendencies
Personal merit consists entirely in durable qualities of mind
External advantages (wealth, rank) have no intrinsic moral merit
Bodily endowments (strength, beauty) have little moral value compared to mental qualities
Natural abilities (ingenuity, memory, penetration) are virtues equal to moral qualities
The common distinction between talents and virtues is merely verbal
The catalogue of virtues varies slightly across nations but utility remains constant
Moral philosophy should be practical and aim to improve character
Experimental method (observation of human nature) is the proper approach to morals
Anatomy of the mind reveals the real springs of moral action
Excessive refinement in moral theory is dangerous and impractical
Moderate skepticism about moral systems promotes humility and tolerance
The ultimate end of morals is the happiness of mankind
Happiness consists in agreeable sentiments and the satisfaction of passions
Social virtues contribute more to public happiness than solitary ones
Justice prevents the clash of interests that would make society miserable
Equity and impartiality in justice are demanded by public utility
International justice (laws of nations) rests on the same principle of mutual advantage
The laws of war and treaties derive their obligation from utility
Moral obligations bind stronger in proportion to the importance of the interest
Small inconveniences do not oblige us to justice when the public interest is not affected
The sense of honour and duty reinforces the natural obligation to justice
Education and custom strengthen the moral sentiment toward justice
Politicians and parents deliberately cultivate the sense of justice in children
The love of fame motivates virtuous actions via sympathy with public praise
The party of humankind arises from the most extensive sympathy
Narrow factional sympathy produces partial and distorted moral judgments
True philosophy enlarges the heart to embrace all mankind
Moral approbation is disinterested yet arises from our own constitution
Self-love, when properly regulated, coincides with social virtue
Unregulated self-love becomes pernicious and antisocial
The general appetite to good and aversion to evil is the foundation of morals
Particular passions are directed toward specific objects; morals concern general tendencies
Virtue is the most excellent quality of the human mind
The moral sentiment is more uniform than tastes in external beauty
Disagreements in aesthetics are greater than in morals because utility is more constant
Moral judgments admit of greater certainty than speculative philosophy
The principles of morals are simple and few when properly analysed
All elaborate moral systems (self-love, rational intuition) fail to explain the facts
The hypothesis of universal self-interest contradicts common experience
Benevolent actions often proceed from immediate instinct, not calculation
The rationalist hypothesis (eternal fitnesses) renders morality cold and unmotivating
Moral distinctions are discovered by sentiment, not by abstract reason
The head is the seat of reason; the heart is the seat of moral sentiment
A perfectly virtuous character combines justice, benevolence, and agreeable qualities
No human has ever attained perfect virtue, but approximation is possible
The study of morals should inspire emulation of virtuous examples
History and biography are the best sources for moral instruction
Moral philosophy without practical effect is worthless
The enquiry into morals should conclude with humility about our limited understanding
The principles here established are permanent and universal features of human nature
Religion did not originate from rational contemplation of the design or order of nature
The earliest form of religion among humans was polytheism, not monotheism
Monotheism is a later historical development that emerged from polytheism
The claim that monotheism was humanity's original religion is historically unfounded
Ancient historical records universally attest to polytheistic origins of religion
No nation achieved monotheism prior to the development of arts and sciences
The vulgar and uneducated masses naturally incline toward polytheism
Theism requires a sophistication of thought absent in primitive conditions
Idolatry universally preceded theism in all nations for which we have records
The notion of a single supreme deity is not intuitive or natural to the untutored mind
Fear is the primary psychological source of religious belief
Hope regarding uncertain future events drives humans toward religion
Anxiety about survival and wellbeing generates religious sentiments
The unknown causes of events in nature provoke religious speculation
Humans personify the unknown causes of fortune and misfortune
People project human qualities onto invisible powers that affect their lives
Self-interested concern with happiness and misery motivates religious belief
The ordinary affairs of life—health, sickness, weather—first prompted religious ideas
Abstract contemplation of nature's order was not the original source of religion
Humans attend first to what immediately affects their wellbeing, not cosmic design
Ignorance of natural causes is the principal source of religion
The more ignorant a people, the more superstitious they tend to be
Scientific understanding diminishes the hold of superstition
Early humans attributed agency to natural phenomena they could not explain
The irregular and unpredictable events of life especially prompt religious attribution
Where causes are known, humans do not invoke supernatural agency
The unknown is naturally filled with invisible intelligent powers
Humans cannot long remain in suspense about unknown causes affecting them
The imagination supplies gods where understanding cannot supply causes
Education and inquiry weaken superstitious tendencies
Humans universally conceive gods in their own image
Anthropomorphism is the natural tendency in all religious thought
Even abstract theological concepts retain anthropomorphic residues
The gods are assigned human passions, desires, and motives
The attribution of human form to deities is nearly universal
Animals, plants, and objects became gods through personification
Every aspect of nature became inhabited by spirits resembling humans
The propensity to anthropomorphize is deeply rooted in human nature
Humans find agency and intention wherever they perceive effects
We project our own mental operations onto external causes
Polytheism distributes divine power among multiple limited beings
The gods of polytheism are conceived as similar to humans but more powerful
Polytheistic gods have particular provinces, domains, and limitations
Polytheism is more tolerant than monotheism of diverse religious practices
Polytheistic societies readily incorporated foreign gods into their pantheons
The gods of polytheism are not infinitely perfect or omnipotent
Polytheism permits a comfortable familiarity between humans and gods
The behavior attributed to polytheistic gods is often morally questionable
Polytheism does not demand exclusive devotion to one deity
Allegiance in polytheism shifts based on circumstances and needs
Monotheism arose from competitive exaltation of particular deities
Flattery of favored gods gradually elevated them above all others
The rhetoric of praise naturally tends toward superlatives and ultimacy
One god becomes supreme through the diminution of rivals
Monotheism represents an endpoint in the logic of divine adulation
The transition from polytheism to monotheism is gradual, not sudden
Fear drives humans to magnify the power of their chosen deity
The desire for divine favor leads to ever-greater attributions of power
Monotheism retains vestiges of polytheism in angels, saints, and demons
The popular religion even in monotheistic cultures resembles polytheism

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: Religion naturally oscillates between polytheistic and monotheistic tendencies

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: The abstraction of monotheism is difficult for ordinary minds to sustain

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: Humans need mediating figures between themselves and an infinite deity

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: The veneration of saints represents a return toward polytheistic sentiment

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: Popular religion constantly reintroduces plurality into official monotheism

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: The flux between unity and plurality is inherent in religious psychology

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: Philosophical theism cannot maintain itself among the general populace

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: Devotion requires objects more tangible than an abstract supreme being

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: The tendency toward anthropomorphic plurality reasserts itself continually

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religious Flux
conclusion: What is officially monotheism becomes practical polytheism in popular practice
Polytheism is more tolerant; monotheism more prone to persecution
Monotheism makes stronger claims and therefore breeds fiercer conflict
Exclusive devotion to one god generates intolerance of other religions
Polytheism lacks the doctrinal rigidity that produces religious violence
Monotheism's greater philosophical coherence comes with social costs
The unity of God generates sectarian disputes about God's true nature
Polytheism allowed diverse peoples to coexist religiously
Monotheistic zeal has produced more cruelty than polytheistic laxity
Persecution for religious belief was rare in polytheistic antiquity
The exclusive claims of monotheism make religious pluralism difficult

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Popular religion has little positive effect on morality

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Religious devotion is often substituted for genuine moral virtue

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: The observances of religion frequently displace ethical behavior

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Superstition can make crimes appear as piety when done for religious ends

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Gods are worshipped more through ritual than through moral conduct

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Frivolous practices are often treated as more important than justice or benevolence

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Religion and morality have historically had an uneasy relationship

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Theological virtues often conflict with natural moral virtues

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Self-denial and austerity are praised beyond social virtues

topic: Natural History of Religion - Religion and Morality
conclusion: Religion can corrupt morality by introducing strange new duties

topic: Natural History of Religion - Human Nature
conclusion: Religious belief arises from universal features of human psychology

topic: Natural History of Religion - Human Nature
conclusion: The sources of religion are natural, not supernatural
Religion should be studied as a natural phenomenon like any other

topic: Natural History of Religion - Human Nature
conclusion: Human nature inevitably generates religious ideas under certain conditions
The religious impulse is not evidence for the truth of religious claims
Understanding how religion arises is distinct from evaluating its truth
The causes of religious belief do not validate its content
Religion reflects the human condition more than cosmic reality
The study of religion belongs to psychology and history, not theology
The natural history of religion reveals human nature, not divine nature
The English constitution was not fixed from time immemorial but evolved gradually through historical contingency
The notion of an "ancient constitution" preserving Saxon liberties is largely mythological
English liberty developed through the slow accumulation of precedents, not from any original founding
The balance between crown and parliament shifted continually throughout English history
Royal prerogative and parliamentary privilege were never precisely defined in earlier ages
Constitutional ambiguity was the source of most conflicts between crown and parliament
Both royalists and parliamentarians could appeal to precedent because precedents were contradictory
The constitution under the Tudors was essentially monarchical with limited parliamentary restraint
Parliament's powers expanded through circumstances rather than through recovery of ancient rights
The Glorious Revolution established constitutional principles that were genuinely novel, not restored
Absolute monarchy is dangerous because it places no check on the ruler's passions
Weak monarchs invite faction and civil disorder
Strong monarchs can advance civilization but risk becoming tyrannical
The personal character of the monarch profoundly affects the course of history
Hereditary succession, despite its flaws, provides stability that election cannot
Royal prerogative was historically extensive and only gradually limited
The Tudors exercised nearly absolute power with general public acceptance
The Stuarts attempted to maintain powers that changing circumstances no longer supported
Charles I's fate resulted from his own duplicity as much as from parliamentary ambition
James II's downfall was caused by his religious zealotry overriding political prudence
Parliament originated as a feudal council, not as a representative democratic body
The House of Commons gradually acquired powers it did not originally possess
Parliamentary claims to ancient rights were often historically unfounded
The Long Parliament's innovations were revolutionary, not conservative
Parliament can become as tyrannical as any monarch when unchecked
The interests of parliament do not automatically align with the interests of the people
Faction within parliament is as dangerous as royal absolutism
Mixed government requires genuine balance, not parliamentary supremacy
The Commons used control of revenue to leverage constitutional concessions
Parliamentary liberty required centuries to develop its modern form
The Civil War resulted from faults on both sides, not from one party's villainy alone
Charles I was not a tyrant but was duplicitous and politically inept
The parliamentary leaders began with legitimate grievances but exceeded all bounds
Religious enthusiasm transformed political disagreement into irreconcilable conflict
The execution of Charles I was a criminal act without legal justification
The war could have been avoided had either side shown more moderation
Economic and social changes made the old constitutional settlement unstable
The gentry's rising wealth increased their political expectations
Puritan zeal made compromise impossible once conflict began
The war's devastation exceeded any grievances that provoked it
Cromwell combined genuine religious conviction with ruthless political ambition
Cromwell's abilities as a military commander were extraordinary
Cromwell's rule was a military despotism disguised by republican forms
The Protectorate demonstrated that parliamentary government requires a monarch or substitute
Cromwell's power rested entirely on the army, not on popular consent
Cromwell suppressed liberty more effectively than the Stuarts ever had
The Protectorate's instability after Cromwell's death proved its dependence on one man
Cromwell's Irish campaign was marked by exceptional cruelty
Cromwell's foreign policy restored English prestige in Europe
The nation welcomed the Restoration because Cromwell's system was exhausted
Religious enthusiasm is the most dangerous source of political disorder
The Reformation in England was driven more by politics than by theology
Henry VIII's break with Rome served royal interests, not Protestant principles
Elizabeth's religious settlement aimed at political stability, not doctrinal purity
Puritan demands for further reformation destabilized the Elizabethan compromise
Catholic plots against Elizabeth justified severe measures of self-defense
James I's handling of Puritans and Catholics alike showed poor judgment
Archbishop Laud's ceremonial innovations provoked unnecessary opposition
Religious uniformity is impossible to achieve and dangerous to attempt
Toleration became possible only after religious zeal exhausted itself through war
The dissolution of monasteries transferred enormous wealth to the crown and nobility
Monastic lands enriched a new class with vested interests in Protestantism
The Marian persecutions created Protestant martyrs and hardened opposition to Rome
Elizabeth's long reign consolidated Protestant establishment irreversibly
The Reformation weakened traditional restraints on royal power initially
Protestant emphasis on scripture promoted literacy and independent thought
The Reformation's political consequences exceeded its theological significance
Religious change proceeded unevenly across different regions and classes
Popular religion changed more slowly than official religious policy
The Reformation created lasting divisions that fueled later conflicts
The progress of commerce gradually softened manners and reduced violence
Feudal barbarism gave way to civilization through economic development
The growth of towns created new centers of wealth independent of landed nobility
Trade promoted peace by creating mutual interests among nations
Luxury, though moralists condemn it, promotes industry and refinement
The middling ranks grew in importance as commerce expanded
Commercial prosperity provided the tax base for effective government
The arts and sciences flourish only under conditions of security and liberty
England's commercial development distinguished it from continental absolutisms
Material progress and moral progress are connected though not identical
The common law developed through accumulated judicial decisions, not legislative enactment
Trial by jury gradually replaced more barbarous forms of adjudication
Torture was employed in England, though less systematically than on the continent
Star Chamber and High Commission represented dangerous concentrations of judicial power
The abolition of prerogative courts was among Parliament's lasting achievements
Habeas corpus protections developed gradually through particular cases
Legal procedures in earlier ages afforded little protection to the accused
The rule of law requires independent judges free from royal pressure
Property rights became more secure as constitutional government developed
Justice in feudal times depended heavily on the power of the litigants
The historian must judge past ages by their own standards, not present ones
Partisanship distorts historical understanding on all sides
Both Whig and Tory interpretations of English history are one-sided
Documentary evidence must be weighed critically, not accepted uncritically
Human nature remains constant; circumstances and manners change
Great events often arise from small and contingent causes
Historical actors rarely foresaw the consequences of their actions
Moral judgment of historical figures requires understanding their situation
National character develops through long historical experience
History teaches moderation by showing the disasters produced by extremism
Henry VII's avarice secured the crown's finances but earned him the hatred of his subjects
Henry VII's policy of weakening the nobility strengthened royal authority for his successors
Henry VIII's personal passions drove matters of state more than any consistent policy
Henry VIII's break with Rome was motivated by lust and dynastic anxiety, not religious conviction
Thomas More's execution displayed Henry's willingness to destroy even loyal servants
Cardinal Wolsey's fall demonstrated the precariousness of ministerial power under a capricious monarch
The Six Articles showed Henry remained Catholic in doctrine while rejecting papal authority
Edward VI's reign was dominated by factional struggles among Protestant nobles
The Duke of Somerset's fall exemplified the dangers of protectorate government
Mary I's sincere Catholicism blinded her to the political costs of persecution
Elizabeth's long reign provided the stability England needed after decades of turmoil
Elizabeth's religious settlement was a masterpiece of political ambiguity
Elizabeth's reluctance to marry preserved her independence but created succession anxieties
Elizabeth's parsimony, though often criticized, maintained crown solvency
Elizabeth's treatment of Mary Queen of Scots was politically necessary but morally dubious
The Elizabethan Poor Laws represented significant social legislation
Elizabeth managed parliament more skillfully than any Stuart
Elizabeth's naval policy laid the foundations for English maritime supremacy
The defeat of the Armada owed as much to weather and Spanish errors as to English valor
Elizabeth's later years saw growing tensions that would explode under her successors

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary Stuart's beauty and charm could not compensate for her political failures

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's marriage to Darnley was disastrous in both personal and political terms

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's complicity in Darnley's murder remains probable though not conclusively proven

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's flight to England placed Elizabeth in an impossible situation

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary became the focus of Catholic conspiracy whether she actively encouraged it or not

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's execution, though politically expedient, violated principles of sovereign immunity

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's claim to the English throne was legally superior to Elizabeth's by strict hereditary right

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: The casket letters, if genuine, demonstrated Mary's guilt in Darnley's death

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's imprisonment lasted nearly twenty years before her execution

topic: History of England - Mary Queen of Scots
conclusion: Mary's son James showed little concern for avenging his mother
James I's learning exceeded his political wisdom
James I's belief in divine right was sincere but politically imprudent to assert so boldly
James I's extravagance reversed the fiscal prudence of Elizabeth's reign
James I's promotion of favorites like Somerset and Buckingham bred resentment
James I's peaceful foreign policy, though sensible, was unpopular with Protestant opinion
The Gunpowder Plot intensified anti-Catholic sentiment for generations
James I's conflicts with parliament foreshadowed the crises of his son's reign
The Added Parliament of 1614 showed the growing dysfunction between crown and Commons
James I's sale of titles debased the honors system and alienated the old nobility
The Spanish Match negotiations revealed James's diplomatic isolation
Charles I possessed more dignity but less flexibility than his father
Charles I's marriage to a Catholic princess aroused Protestant suspicions
Buckingham's influence over Charles proved as disastrous as over James
The Petition of Right represented parliament's clearest statement of constitutional grievance
Charles's personal rule from 1629 to 1640 was legally dubious but practically effective
Ship money was technically within royal prerogative but violated the spirit of constitutional practice
Charles's attempt to impose religious uniformity on Scotland ignited the conflicts that destroyed him
The Short Parliament's failure demonstrated Charles's inability to manage political opposition
The Long Parliament initially enjoyed broad support across political factions
Strafford's execution was judicial murder to which Charles shamefully consented
The Rump Parliament represented only a fraction of the political nation
The regicide was the work of a determined minority, not popular will
The Commonwealth never achieved legitimacy or stable institutions
The army's political interventions prevented any constitutional settlement
The Levellers represented radical ideas that the Grandees would not tolerate
The Diggers' experiments in communal living were suppressed as threatening property
The navigation acts under the Commonwealth advanced English commercial interests
The Dutch War showed the republic's capacity for aggressive foreign policy
The Nominated Parliament demonstrated the impossibility of godly rule
The Instrument of Government created a constitution that satisfied no one
The Restoration occurred because all alternatives had failed, not from royalist enthusiasm
Charles II's easy manners contrasted favorably with Puritan severity
The Act of Indemnity was politically necessary despite leaving crimes unpunished
The Clarendon Code imposed Anglican uniformity more strictly than Charles wished
Charles II's secret Catholic sympathies complicated his entire reign
The Treaty of Dover revealed Charles's willingness to betray Protestant interests for French gold
The Cabal ministry represented faction rather than coherent policy
The Test Act forced Catholics from public office but Charles evaded its spirit
The Popish Plot hysteria showed how easily public fear could be manipulated
Shaftesbury's exploitation of the Plot was cynical but politically effective
The attempt to exclude James from the succession threatened hereditary right itself
Charles II's resistance to Exclusion showed his only consistent principle
The emergence of Whig and Tory parties dates from the Exclusion Crisis
The Oxford Parliament's dissolution demonstrated Charles's political mastery
The Rye House Plot discredited the Whigs and enabled royalist reaction
The judicial murders of Russell and Sidney were revenge for Exclusion
Charles II's final years saw royal power at its highest point since the Civil War
Charles II's deathbed conversion to Catholicism confirmed long-held suspicions
The Tory doctrine of non-resistance would be tested by James II's policies
The Exclusion Crisis left wounds that shaped the Revolution of 1688
James II's Catholicism was sincere, which made him more dangerous than a politique
James II initially enjoyed goodwill that his policies rapidly dissipated
The suppression of Monmouth's rebellion was followed by Jeffreys' Bloody Assizes
James's dispensing power claims threatened the entire statutory framework
The Declaration of Indulgence aimed at Catholic emancipation under cover of toleration
The prosecution of the Seven Bishops united Anglican and dissenting opinion
The birth of James's son made a Catholic succession imminent rather than temporary
The invitation to William of Orange came from a desperate political nation
James's flight simplified a situation that might otherwise have produced civil war
The Convention Parliament's settlement was revolutionary despite claims of continuity
William III cared more for European war against France than for English domestic affairs
The Bill of Rights established parliamentary limitations on royal power definitively
The Toleration Act represented practical accommodation rather than principled pluralism
The financial settlement made the crown permanently dependent on parliament
The Act of Settlement secured Protestant succession against Stuart claims
William's Dutch favorites aroused English xenophobic resentment
Mary II's death removed William's strongest claim to English loyalty
The Bank of England's creation revolutionized public finance
The wars against Louis XIV burdened England with unprecedented national debt
The Revolution Settlement proved durable because it balanced competing interests
Money is not the wheel of trade but only its oil or instrument
An increase in money, with quantities of labor and commodities fixed, merely raises prices proportionally
The quantity theory of money: prices are in proportion to the quantity of money in circulation
A gradual increase in money stimulates industry before prices fully adjust
Sudden increases in money cause temporary prosperity followed by higher prices
All augmentations of money are ultimately neutral in real terms but beneficial if slow
Luxury is not injurious to a state but rather promotes industry and refinement
Refinement in the arts (luxury) increases labor demand and raises wages
Consumption of luxuries encourages invention, arts, and economic activity
Frugality in individuals may be virtuous, but general frugality contracts commerce
Interest rates are determined primarily by the demand and supply of borrowing, not by the quantity of money
High profits on capital, not abundance of money, are the true cause of high interest rates
Low interest rates result from increased commerce and accumulation of capital
In a commercial society, interest rates naturally fall over time
The balance of trade is not a reliable indicator of national prosperity
An unfavorable balance of trade automatically corrects itself via the specie-flow mechanism
When a nation exports more than it imports, specie flows in, raising prices and restoring equilibrium
Attempts to hoard specie by prohibiting export are futile and harmful
Free trade is generally more advantageous than protectionist policies
Jealousy of trade among nations is based on mistaken zero-sum assumptions
Every nation benefits from the economic prosperity of its neighbors
Rich trading nations are the best customers and suppliers for others
Tariffs and trade restrictions usually harm the country that imposes them
The wealth of a nation consists in the abundance of commodities and labor, not in gold and silver
Bullion and coin are merely conventional representations of real wealth
Public credit (government debt) can be useful in emergencies but dangerous when excessive
Perpetual public debt transfers wealth from industrious citizens to idle stockholders
Heavy taxation to service public debt discourages industry and population growth
Voluntary national bankruptcy would ruin credit and should be avoided
A growing public debt ultimately leads to higher taxes or debasement of currency
Taxes on consumption are generally preferable to taxes on land or capital
Taxes should be certain, convenient, and proportionate to ability to pay
Indirect taxes (excises) are less felt and often less burdensome than direct ones
High wages are a sign of national prosperity, not distress
Low wages result from scarcity of labor or lack of demand for it
Population tends to adjust to the demand for labor and means of subsistence
A flourishing economy naturally increases population
Ancient nations were not more populous than modern ones; evidence suggests the contrary
Slavery and political oppression in antiquity reduced effective population
Modern European liberty and security of property encourage greater populousness
Commerce enlarges the market and encourages division of labor
Division of labor increases productivity and national wealth
Manufactures and commerce mutually support each other
Agriculture benefits from proximity to manufacturing and commercial towns
Enclosure and improvement of land are promoted by commercial demand
Paper credit and banking facilitate commerce by economizing on specie
Banks of circulation (note-issuing) are beneficial when properly managed
Excessive issue of paper money causes inflation and harms trade
International lending and borrowing equalize interest rates across nations
Capital flows to where profits are highest, equalizing returns over time
No nation can long remain both creditor and manufacturer to the world
The riches of a nation are measured by the annual produce of its labor and industry
Foreign trade multiplies domestic goods by exchanging superfluities for necessities or conveniences
Protection of infant industries may sometimes be justified temporarily
Navigation acts favoring domestic shipping can be advantageous despite restricting trade
Colonies enrich the mother country by extending its commerce
Exclusive colonial trade privileges are beneficial to the metropolis
Free ports and entrepôts increase national commerce
Monopolies granted to trading companies are generally pernicious
Bounties on exports usually waste public revenue without real benefit
Drawing prizes (lotteries) for public loans encourage excessive borrowing
Sinking funds for debt repayment are often illusory and mismanaged
A national debt may act as a kind of political mortgage binding citizens to government
In a commercial state, the middle class becomes the most numerous and influential
Commerce softens manners and promotes humanity
Industry, knowledge, and humanity are linked by inseparable bonds
The spirit of the age tends toward greater economic liberty
Absolute governments are less favorable to commerce than free ones
Moderate taxation encourages industry; oppressive taxation destroys it
Sumptuary laws attempting to restrain luxury are ineffective and harmful
Fashion and taste changes stimulate continual demand for labor
The desire for luxuries spreads from the rich downward through society
Artisans and merchants gain most from refined consumption
A large stock of capital is necessary for extensive division of labor
Capital accumulation lowers profits and interest rates over time
The rate of profit tends toward equality across different employments
Money is distributed among nations according to their industry and commerce
No nation can acquire excessive specie relative to its economic activity
Price levels naturally adjust to the quantity of money and velocity of circulation
Velocity of money increases in commercial societies
Banks increase the effective velocity of money
Low interest encourages investment in land improvement
High interest discourages long-term agricultural projects
The natural progress of opulence is from agriculture to manufactures to foreign trade
Many European policies reverse this natural order to the detriment of wealth
Freedom of trade within a country is essential for prosperity
Internal tolls and customs hinder domestic commerce
Standardization of weights, measures, and coinage facilitates exchange
Good roads, canals, and communication promote economic integration
Invention and improvement flourish most under commercial liberty
The law of one price tends to prevail across connected markets
Arbitrage equalizes commodity prices internationally
Exchange rates fluctuate around the specie points determined by transport costs
Bills of exchange are the true balance of trade mechanism
A general scarcity of money is impossible in a commercial world
Particular scarcities arise only from temporary disruptions
Public granaries to stabilize grain prices usually do more harm than good
The corn bounty encourages tillage but at excessive public cost
Economic prosperity depends more on institutions and manners than on natural resources
The same principles of political economy apply universally, though modified by particular circumstances
Commerce tends to produce liberty by creating an independent middle rank
Free governments are generally more favourable to economic progress than absolute ones
The spirit of commerce spreads knowledge and moderates religious fanaticism
Industry and refinement mutually reinforce each other
A taste for luxury first appears among the higher ranks and gradually descends
The multiplication of wants is the true engine of economic activity
General plenty lowers the price of labour only temporarily; demand soon catches up
High wages stimulate population growth by making marriage and child-rearing easier
Low wages in poor countries are the effect, not the cause, of poverty
The real wealth of neighbours increases our own absolute wealth through trade
Jealousy of trade rests on the false assumption that one nation's gain is another's loss
Mutual prosperity among trading nations is the true commercial interest
Restrictions on foreign luxury goods ultimately hurt domestic industry
The prohibition of exporting specie is both unnecessary and counterproductive
Specie naturally distributes itself in proportion to each nation's trade and industry
No nation ever became poor merely by importing goods and exporting money
An influx of specie first benefits manufacturers and labourers before landlords
Rising prices caused by new money stimulate every branch of commerce
A sudden contraction of money supply would be more harmful than gradual inflation
Paper money is useful when it represents real capital and circulates confidently
Excessive paper credit without sufficient specie reserve leads to collapse
Public banks properly regulated are a great advantage to commerce
Private banking companies often innovate more than state monopolies
Interest is the barometer of the abundance or scarcity of capital
Profits on stock fall as commerce extends and capital accumulates
The legal rate of interest should follow, not lead, the market rate
Usury laws that fix interest too low drive capital abroad or into concealment
High interest in rude societies reflects high profits and risk, not scarcity of money
Low interest in polished nations reflects accumulated capital and security
The progress of society naturally lowers both profits and interest
Taxes on luxuries are paid ultimately by the consumer, not the seller
Heavy taxation of necessities falls hardest on the poor
Proportional taxation is more equitable than regressive excises in principle
In practice, indirect taxes are easier to collect and less oppressive
A land tax is the most equitable direct tax but difficult to assess fairly
Taxes on houses are less burdensome than on windows or hearths
Arbitrary taxation without consent destroys industry and liberty
Public debt allows a nation to exert strength beyond its annual revenue in war
Perpetual funded debt creates a moneyed interest separate from the landed interest
The moneyed interest tends to support liberty against arbitrary power
Excessive public debt risks transferring property from active to idle classes
A large national debt may make taxation politically easier in the short run
Creditors of the public eventually become dependent on the state's stability
National bankruptcy would destroy confidence more than gradual repayment
Sinking funds are usually illusory and diverted to current expenses
Voluntary loans are preferable to forced loans or anticipations
The British system of public credit is an extraordinary modern invention
Colonial trade enriches the mother country more than equivalent European trade
Exclusive companies for colonial trade often stifle commerce
Free trade with colonies would benefit both parties more than monopoly
Navigation Acts strengthen naval power at some cost to general commerce
Bounties on production rarely compensate for the taxes required to fund them
Export bounties distort the natural allocation of capital
Corn export bounties encourage over-production and price instability
The price of corn regulates wages more than any other commodity
Free exportation of corn prevents extreme dearness in bad years
The assize of bread is an ineffective interference with market prices
The division of labour is limited by the extent of the market
Large cities promote arts, industry, and knowledge through competition
Rural isolation breeds ignorance and stagnation
Good police (administration) is essential for secure commerce
Uniform justice and protection of property are the foundations of prosperity
Arbitrary power in judges or magistrates destroys confidence in contracts
Freedom of the press aids commerce by spreading useful knowledge
Toleration of religious sects promotes industry by attracting skilled foreigners
Persecution drives away the most industrious citizens
Invention flourishes best under liberty and security
Monopolies granted to inventors should be temporary and moderate
Perpetual patents would hinder rather than encourage improvement
Policies that force manufactures before agriculture are usually mistaken
Enclosure of common lands generally increases agricultural productivity
Large farms are more efficient than small ones for grain production
Small properties encourage intensive gardening and horticulture
Security of inheritance is necessary for long-term land improvement
Primogeniture and entails preserve large estates but hinder alienation
Freedom to alienate land would accelerate agricultural progress
The feudal system of tenure long retarded improvement in Europe
Money rents are more favourable to improvement than rents in kind
Long leases at fixed rents encourage tenant investment
The rise of commerce gradually dissolved feudal dependencies
The power of the commons in Britain arose from the growth of trade
A numerous and independent gentry supports both liberty and industry
Excessive concentration of land ownership threatens despotism
Moderate inequality of fortune is compatible with flourishing commerce
Extreme equality would destroy emulation and industry
Extreme inequality destroys the middle rank necessary for liberty
The balance of power in Europe favours commerce by preventing universal monarchy
A universal monarchy would stagnate trade through uniformity and oppression
Alliances and treaties should aim at commercial as well as political equilibrium
Economic interdependence makes modern wars more costly and less frequent
Standing armies are dangerous to liberty but sometimes necessary for security
A well-regulated militia is the best security for a commercial nation
Heavy war taxes fall ultimately on rent and profits
War financed by debt shifts the burden to future generations
Peace and low taxes are the surest foundations of long-term prosperity
All objects of human reason divide into two kinds: relations of ideas and matters of fact
Knowledge of matters of fact never achieves the certainty of demonstration; it rests entirely on experience
The mind never has access to external objects themselves, only to perceptions
Belief in the external world is not rationally grounded but arises from natural propensities of the imagination
The supposition that our perceptions resemble external objects is groundless
Theoretical knowledge about matters of fact reduces to vivid ideas associated with present impressions through custom
Skeptical arguments against the senses and reason are unanswerable by reason, but nature renders them impotent
We never perceive any necessary connection between cause and effect; we perceive only constant conjunction
The idea of necessary connection arises from an internal impression: the felt determination of the mind
Causal knowledge is entirely founded on experience; there is no a priori insight into what causes what
A single observation of conjunction provides no basis for causal inference; only repeated observation instills habit
The "power" or "force" we attribute to causes is a projection onto objects of what is actually subjective
Causal reasoning is a species of instinct, implanted by nature to serve practical life
We can never perceive why a cause produces its effect; we can only observe that it does so regularly
All reasoning concerning matters of fact is founded on the relation of cause and effect
The inference from observed to unobserved cases is founded on custom operating on the imagination
The uniformity of nature cannot itself be established by argument without circularity
Probable reasoning differs from demonstrative reasoning in that its conclusions can be conceived false
The degree of belief is proportioned to the constancy of the observed conjunction
Inference from experience is not a product of the understanding but of the imagination
We have no rational assurance that our inferences about unobserved matters will prove true
Relations of ideas can be known with certainty because their denial implies a contradiction
Knowledge of relations of ideas is discovered by the mere operation of thought
Propositions concerning relations of ideas are intuitively or demonstratively certain
Mathematical truths concern the relations among our ideas of quantity and number
The certainty of mathematics arises from the fact that we can define our terms precisely
Geometry is less certain than algebra and arithmetic because it involves ideas of extension
Even in mathematics, complex demonstrations can produce less than perfect certainty
All knowledge concerning matters of fact is founded entirely on experience
Knowledge of matters of fact is always probable, never demonstratively certain
We can never know a priori that one event will follow another
The evidence of memory and the senses provides the foundation for all factual knowledge
Our confidence in synthetic knowledge rests on the vivacity of ideas, not rational insight
Knowledge of unobserved matters of fact always involves an inference governed by custom
We cannot justify our factual beliefs by appeal to first principles; justification bottoms out in instinct
When I enter most intimately into what I call myself, I always stumble on some particular perception
There is no impression of a self from which the idea of self could be derived
What we call the self is nothing but a bundle or collection of different perceptions
The identity we ascribe to the mind is a fictitious one, produced by the imagination
Self-knowledge is limited to knowledge of present perceptions
Memory is the chief source of the notion of personal identity
The question of personal identity is in some sense insoluble
The self is not a substance or substratum in which perceptions inhere
Personal identity is not a real tie among perceptions but a quality we attribute to them
The mind is a kind of theatre where perceptions successively make their appearance
Resemblance among perceptions causes the imagination to feign identity
Causation among perceptions further strengthens the fiction of personal identity
The dispute about personal identity concerns what we call the same person, not metaphysical fact
The self is a useful fiction, necessary for practical life
Passions are original existences, not representations of anything
Reason alone can never be a motive to any action of the will
Reason is, and ought only to be, the slave of the passions
Passions are impressions of reflection, arising from previous impressions
The direct passions arise immediately from pleasure and pain
The indirect passions require a double relation of impressions and ideas
Pride and humility are directed toward the self; love and hatred toward other persons
Sympathy is the mechanism by which we enter into the sentiments of others
Passions can be calm or violent; calm passions may be mistaken for reason
We do not first judge and then feel; the feeling is primary
Custom operates on the mind below the threshold of explicit awareness
The imagination performs its operations without our direction or awareness
Many associations of ideas occur instantaneously and without reflection
The felt determination to pass from cause to effect is often registered only obscurely
Habit and custom establish patterns of inference that function automatically
The mind's propensity to spread itself on external objects operates without awareness
We may be moved by calm passions without recognizing them as passions
The mind has a great propensity to spread itself on external objects
Necessary connection, power, and force are projected onto causes from internal impressions
We gild and stain natural objects with colors borrowed from internal sentiment
The projection of internal impressions onto objects is a natural operation of the imagination
We mistake the propensity of the mind for a perceived connection in objects
Secondary qualities are projections of internal impressions onto external objects
The vulgar naturally reify their projections; philosophy discovers but cannot eradicate them
Failure to recognize projection is a source of metaphysical error
Men are more governed by their passions than by their reason
Reason is often enlisted after the fact to defend conclusions reached on other grounds
Our causal reasonings are often distorted by passion
The influence of passion on judgment is pervasive but often invisible
Self-love biases our judgments about our own conduct
The love of system can lead philosophers to force facts into preferred frameworks
Religious belief and moral conviction are particularly susceptible to rationalization
We are generally poor judges of our own motives
Certain fundamental principles operate prior to all custom: belief in continued existence, causal expectations, sympathy
The inference from cause to effect is a species of natural instinct
Sympathy is a fundamental principle of human nature
Self-love and benevolence are both original principles; neither reduces to the other
Curiosity or the love of truth is a natural passion motivating inquiry
The moral sense is natural to man
The aesthetic sense is similarly natural
These instincts are the foundation of all human thought and action
Nature has not left it to our choice whether to believe, infer, and feel
By liberty we can only mean a power of acting according to the determinations of the will
Hypothetical liberty is universally allowed to everyone not a prisoner
A liberty of indifference is not only impossible but unintelligible
The feeling of freedom in deliberation is merely ignorance of determining causes
When we act, we act from motives arising from character and circumstance
Freedom is compatible with regular connection between motive and action
The dispute about liberty and necessity has been merely verbal
There is a uniform and regular conjunction between motives and actions
The necessity we attribute to causes is the mind's determination to pass from cause to effect
Actions are necessitated in the same sense that physical events are necessitated
Human nature is uniform across times and cultures in its fundamental operations
We constantly draw inferences about human behavior based on known motives
If actions did not proceed necessarily from motives, praise and blame would lose their point
The doctrine of necessity does not degrade human nature or eliminate moral responsibility
Liberty and necessity are compatible; liberty without necessity would lack character or meaning
We hold men responsible for actions that flow from their characters
A man who acts from a bad motive displays a bad character; this connection grounds moral judgment
Punishment aims to influence future conduct through the mechanism of motive
The sense of freedom men feel in acting is not falsified by determinism
What we fear in determinism is external compulsion, not internal determination
A universe in which character did not determine action would make persons unintelligible agents
History is the great teacher of human nature; it shows the same motives producing the same actions
The uniformity of human nature makes history possible and valuable
Historical knowledge is based on testimony; credibility must be weighed against probability
The historian must exercise judgment about credibility; extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence
History reveals the operation of general causes on human action through universal principles
The superstitious and marvelous elements in ancient history should be discounted
A philosophical historian attends not only to events but to causes of events
The study of history corrects the parochialism of the present
Suicide is not necessarily a transgression of our duty to God, our neighbor, or ourselves
If suicide be criminal, it must be a transgression of our duty either to God, to our neighbor, or to ourselves
The life of a man is of no greater importance to the universe than that of an oyster
Disposing of one's own life cannot disturb the order of the universe any more than diverting a river
The soul's immortality cannot be proven by reason; it is a matter of revelation alone
Metaphysical arguments for immortality are obscure and uncertain
The moral arguments for immortality presuppose what they seek to prove
Physical arguments suggest the soul is mortal since it depends on bodily organization
Nature does nothing in vain; if souls were immortal, they would not begin with infancy's imbecility
National characters arise from moral causes (government, social circumstances) more than physical causes (climate)
The same nation may have very different characters in different ages
Where several neighboring nations have close communication, they acquire a similitude of manners
Priests of all religions tend toward similar characters despite doctrinal differences
Superstition and enthusiasm are the two corruptions of true religion
Superstition arises from weakness, fear, melancholy, and ignorance
Enthusiasm arises from hope, pride, presumption, and warm imagination
Superstition is favorable to priestly power; enthusiasm is destructive of it
Enthusiasm, though initially more furious, becomes more favorable to civil liberty over time
Superstition renders men tame and abject and fits them for slavery
