The spirit of enthusiasm being contrary to all ecclesiastical power, promotes tolerance
Tragedy gives pleasure by exciting passions of terror and pity in a controlled context
The pleasure of tragedy derives from the eloquence and art with which melancholy passions are represented
Subordinate passions are converted into the dominant passion, adding force to it
The fiction of tragedy renders the passion agreeable that would otherwise be painful
Imitation always gives pleasure, even of objects that would displease in reality
The standard of taste, though variable in individuals, admits of general principles
Strong sense, united to delicate sentiment, improved by practice and comparison, constitutes true taste
The joint verdict of qualified critics constitutes the true standard of taste
Prejudice destroys sound judgment and perverts all operations of the intellectual faculties
Good sense is a part of good taste; they are inseparable
Some forms and qualities are calculated to please and others to displease by the structure of the mind
Blemishes in moral character prejudice us against works, even when the author is long dead
Speculative opinions differ from morals in their influence on taste
The rules of composition are founded on experience and observation of common sentiments
Eloquence at its highest pitch leaves little room for reason or reflection
Modern eloquence is more calm and rational than ancient eloquence
The sublimity of ancient eloquence suited republican governments where the populace decided
Reasoning alone without eloquence has little influence on mankind
The original contract is a philosophical fiction; no government was founded on consent
Tacit consent is a meaningless notion when subjects have no real power to refuse
Obedience to government arises from utility and habit, not from original promise
Most governments began in usurpation or conquest without pretense of consent
The doctrine of passive obedience is as absurd as that of the original contract
Resistance to tyranny is justified when government becomes incompatible with public good
Political parties arise from interest, principle, or affection
Factions from interest are the most reasonable and excusable
Factions from principle, especially abstract speculative principle, are the most extraordinary
Personal factions arise from personal friendship or animosity among leaders
Court and country parties are inherent in mixed governments
The balance of power among European nations preserves liberty against universal monarchy
Excessive concern with the balance of power can itself become a source of war
Perfect equality of possessions would destroy all subordination and reduce society to indigence
The best government is one that provides for its own amendment and reformation
A large state can be governed as a republic through properly structured representation
Small republics are subject to faction; large ones prevent any single faction from dominating
Refinement in the arts promotes humanity and softens tempers
Ages of refinement are both the happiest and most virtuous
Industry, knowledge, and humanity are bound together and promote each other
A progress in the arts is favorable to liberty and unfavorable to arbitrary power
The rise and progress of arts and sciences requires a free government at their origin
Arts and sciences once established can be transplanted into any government
Neighboring free states stimulate emulation and improvement
Republics are initially most favorable to science; civilized monarchies to polite arts
Nothing is more favorable to the rise of civility than a number of neighboring states
The world is yet too young to establish general truths in politics
Commerce can flourish under absolute governments if they are administered with moderation
All kinds of government, free and absolute, have their particular inconveniences
Polygamy is excluded from free governments because it enslaves half the species
Polygamy tends to render one half the species insignificant and the other unhappy
The practice of divorce was more reasonable in Roman than in modern times
The indissolubility of marriage prevents worse evils than it causes
Avarice is the spur of industry; luxury provides the pleasure and recompense
A state is never in greater danger than when all power is lodged in a single person
The first lesson of princes should be to reject the counsel of flatterers
The governors have nothing to support them but opinion; force is always on the side of the governed
Opinion of interest and opinion of right sustain all governments
Ancient governments were more turbulent but modern governments more oppressive
Liberty is the perfection of civil society, but authority must be acknowledged essential to its existence
The middling rank of men is the firmest basis of public liberty
Philosophical skepticism should moderate confidence in speculative opinions
Academic or moderate skepticism is the truest philosophy and most useful to life
Pyrrhonian or excessive skepticism is self-refuting and cannot be maintained
Nature by an absolute and uncontroulable necessity has determin'd us to judge as well as breathe
Philosophy would render us entirely Pyrrhonian were not nature too strong for it
The imagination runs from cause to effect with a facility that prevents close inspection
False philosophy arises from the natural propensities of imagination unchecked by reflection
True philosophy approaches the sentiments of the vulgar with greater circumspection
Abstract reasoning alone can never establish any matter of fact
In every judgment formed concerning probability, there is a secret opposition between imagination and reason
The rules by which we judge of causes and effects are formed by experience alone
Analogical reasoning becomes weaker as the resemblance between cases diminishes
No event is intrinsically miraculous; the term miraculous is relative to our experience
Testimony for miracles must be weighed against the unbroken uniformity of experience
The knavery and folly of men are such common phenomena that miracles should be suspected
A miracle can never be proven so as to be the foundation of a system of religion
The Christian religion was attended with miracles at first but now appeals to reason
Mere reason is insufficient to convince us of the veracity of the Christian religion
Whoever is moved by faith to assent to scripture has a continued miracle in his own person
The whole frame of nature bespeaks an intelligent author, but the inference is weak
From the present scene of things we can conclude nothing concerning the origin of the world
